video_caption: The video begins with a white screen that transitions to a graphic displaying the words "OPEN ACCESS" in bold blue letters, surrounded by smaller text that reads "FREE," "IMMEDIATE," "ONLINE," "RESEARCH ARTICLES," "AVAILABILITY," and "RE-USE RIGHTS." The background is white, and the text is black, with the words "OPEN ACCESS" highlighted in blue. The scene then shifts to a cartoon illustration of a globe with papers flying around it, accompanied by a speech bubble that says, "This is about making all scientific research content available for anyone anywhere in the world." The globe is colored in blue and green, and the papers are white with black text. The next frame shows a cartoon scientist holding papers, with a speech bubble that reads, "...to read and access and build upon..." The scientist is wearing a white lab coat and glasses, and the background is white. The following frame depicts two cartoon characters looking at papers in the air, with a speech bubble that says, "...so people can do interesting things in new ways with the materials." The characters are drawn in black and white, and the background is white. The final frame shows two cartoon characters, one holding a clipboard, with a speech bubble that reads, "The idea is to make the research literature more..." The background is white, and the characters are drawn in black and white. The video concludes with a white screen.

The video begins with a white screen that transitions to a black-and-white cartoon illustration of two characters, one holding a document and the other a clipboard, engaged in a conversation. The text above them reads, "The History of the model is that publishing scientific manuscripts was..." which then changes to "...expensive." A speech bubble with a dollar sign appears, indicating the cost involved. The scene expands to show more characters, some holding documents and others working at a table, with the text, "If you wanted your article distributed widely, you sent it to a journal." The narrative continues with the characters managing the review process, revisions, and eventually accepting manuscripts. The text explains, "They would manage the review process, revisions and eventually something would get accepted... and they handled the typesetting and printing and distribution of your scientific work." The final frames depict a printing press in operation, with papers flying out, and the text, "And it worked! Science progressed," accompanied by an hourglass and a stack of papers, symbolizing the advancement of science through the publishing process. The video illustrates the historical model of scientific publishing, emphasizing the role of journals in managing and distributing scientific work.

The video begins with a scene depicting a group of people in a scientific setting, engaged in discussions and examining papers. The text "And it worked! Science progressed" is displayed alongside an hourglass and papers, symbolizing the advancement of scientific knowledge. The scene transitions to a white background with the text "What's changed is two things:" followed by the word "Digitization," accompanied by illustrations of individuals using laptops and computers, indicating the shift towards digital technology. The narrative continues with the text "Price Increases" and shows a person handing over a bill to a librarian, highlighting the rising costs associated with scientific publications. The final frames depict a group of people observing the situation, with the text "It's become the theater of the absurd with the amount that some journals want libraries to pay," emphasizing the absurdity of the high costs imposed on libraries. The video uses a combination of illustrations and text to convey the impact of digitization and price increases on scientific progress and access to knowledge.

The video begins with a white background displaying a text that reads, "Research has shown journal prices have outpaced inflation by over 250% over the past thirty years." This sets the context for the discussion on the rising costs of academic journals. The scene transitions to a simple line graph with the years 1986 and 2003 marked on the horizontal axis, indicating a timeline. A stack of books appears, with a speech bubble stating, "There are over 15 entire disciplines where the average prices for one journal is over $1000/year." This highlights the significant financial burden on researchers. The books are then labeled with specific prices and disciplines, such as "Chemistry" at $4223 and "Physics" at $3649, further emphasizing the high costs. The source of the information is cited as the "Library Journal 2012 Periodicals Pricing Survey."

The narrative continues with a graph titled "Price Increases," showing a steep upward trend from 1986 to 2003, with a 260% increase in journal unit cost compared to inflation. A speech bubble states, "Research has shown journal prices have outpaced inflation by over 250% over the past thirty years," reinforcing the initial statement. Below the graph, a stack of books is labeled with various disciplines and their respective prices, such as "Biology" at $2281 and "Agriculture" at $1317. A cartoon character holding a money bag exclaims, "There's a journal that's $40,000!" This exaggerates the cost disparity. The scene shifts to a group of people sitting on a pile of papers, with speech bubbles expressing frustration: "The journals aren't producing the material...," "They don't employ the people who write the papers...," and "They don't even employ the reviewers!" This illustrates the disconnect between the high costs and the actual production and review processes. The video concludes with a person raising their arms in exasperation, accompanied by the text, "It doesn't make sense in terms of what science is supposed to be about," underscoring the absurdity of the situation. The overall atmosphere is one of critique and concern regarding the financial aspects of academic publishing.

The video begins with a black and white cartoon featuring a large building with a dome, representing a government or institutional structure. At the top of the building, several figures are depicted, some holding papers and others engaged in discussion. Below, a crowd of people stands, and a man with a backpack is shown receiving money from a box labeled with a dollar sign, symbolizing financial transactions. The text in the cartoon reads, "They don't employ the people who write the papers... They don't even employ the reviewers! It's so irrational to think that scientists are paid by taxpayers to do research and distribute it... to people." This highlights the disconnect between taxpayers funding research and the lack of direct employment for those involved in the research process.

The scene transitions to a white background with text that reads, "A lot of people just sort of move on and think, 'Well, this is the way it is.' They don't realize there's a whole system behind it." This text emphasizes the lack of awareness about the underlying system that governs access to research and education.

The next frame shows three individuals, one of whom is sitting at a computer with an "Access Denied" message on the screen. The person at the computer appears frustrated, while the other two individuals look on with concern. The text above them reads, "A lot of people just sort of move on and think, 'Well, this is the way it is.' They don't realize there's a whole system behind it." This scene illustrates the frustration and confusion faced by individuals when they encounter barriers to accessing information.

The video then transitions to a maze-like structure with brick walls, representing the complex and often inaccessible system of academic literature. Several individuals are shown navigating the maze, with some encountering "Access Denied" messages on their computer screens. The text in this frame reads, "But your education depends on access to the journal literature. Professors can only have access to..." This highlights the challenges faced by students and researchers in accessing academic literature.

The final frame shows a group of individuals in a maze-like structure, with some of them looking frustrated and others appearing to be in conversation. The text reads, "Students and researchers in low and middle income countries really struggle. It prevents them from contributing fully to world class research." This emphasizes the impact of limited access to academic literature on students and researchers in low and middle-income countries, hindering their ability to contribute to global research efforts. The video concludes with a call to action, urging viewers to support open access to research and education

The video begins with a white screen featuring a small black circle in the center, which then transitions to a scene with two cartoon characters. One character, with blue hair, is speaking to another character with curly hair and a plaid shirt, expressing skepticism about the Public Library of Science. The scene shifts to a hospital room with a patient in bed and an IV drip, where the curly-haired character is seen using a laptop. The character explains that they were up at 3 am in the hospital, next to their wife, trying to find information about a critical medical treatment on the internet. The narrative continues with the character struggling to access the necessary papers, leading to a tense moment where medical professionals are unable to provide answers. The video then shows the character sitting at a desk, frustrated with the situation, and concludes with a message about the problem of accessing articles and the difficulty of understanding abstracts. Throughout the video, the background remains simple, focusing on the characters and their actions, with text providing context to the dialogue and situation.

The video begins with two men standing in front of a 'NO RETURNS' sign, discussing the challenges of academic research. One man, with curly hair and a beard, holds a paper and exclaims, 'This is wrong!' while the other, with blue hair and glasses, points out that abstracts don't always clarify what is contained and there's no return policy. The scene transitions to a man sitting at a desk, working on a laptop, surrounded by dollar bills, indicating the financial burden of research. The text reads, 'So now are you going to spend $1200 to just find out if possibly they're relevant?' The next frame shows the man falling into a hole, with the text, 'If you do that every day, you're in a big hole!' The video then shifts to a man sitting on a sign that reads 'FREE RESEARCH,' with a cartoon image of a bearded man below the text. The man says, 'I'm not a communist,' while another man looks on. The video concludes with the cartoon image of the bearded man raising his fist, symbolizing solidarity and support for free research.

The video features a cartoon-style comic strip that discusses the concept of free research and publishing. It begins with two characters standing next to a banner that reads "FREE RESEARCH," with one character saying, "I'm not a communist. Nobody is saying Publishing is FREE." The scene then transitions to a discussion about the need for government models where the government pays for every step of publishing, illustrated by a large blue sign labeled "PUBLISHING" and a brick wall labeled "RESTRICTED." The characters continue their dialogue, with one character suggesting that the knowledge should be distributed freely and not restricted. The comic strip is set against a simple background with a light blue sky and a white ground, and the characters are depicted in a simplistic, cartoonish style. The comic strip is marked with the text "CC CREATIVE COMMONS" and the website "www.PHDCOMICS.com" at the bottom. The overall atmosphere of the comic strip is educational and thought-provoking, aiming to convey the importance of free and unrestricted access to knowledge.

The video begins with a close-up of the word "OPEN" in bold black letters against a light blue background, followed by the word "ACCESS" in the same style, completing the phrase "OPEN ACCESS." The scene transitions to a green banner with the text "FREE TO READ" in black, accompanied by a cartoon illustration of four people standing together, each holding a book or document. The banner then expands to include a second green section with the text "FREE TO RE-USE" and a grid of empty squares, suggesting the potential for interaction and reuse of content. A caption above the grid reads, "Researcher can build new tools that can interact with articles and uncover new relationships." The video continues to show two individuals reading documents, with one person using a computer to interact with the grid, highlighting the concept of building tools to analyze and connect information. The final frame introduces a group of four people, each holding a document, with a caption stating, "Right now, if you wanted to do that, you couldn't, because you'd have to negotiate rights with every single publisher." The video concludes with the website "WWW.PHDCOICS.COM" displayed at the bottom, indicating the source of the content. Throughout the video, the atmosphere is educational and informative, emphasizing the benefits of open access and the potential for researchers to build tools for analyzing and connecting information.

The video begins with a green background featuring the text "READ" at the top, accompanied by illustrations of four individuals holding papers, seemingly engaged in reading or discussion. Below them, a speech bubble reads, "Right now, if you wanted to do that, you couldn't, because you'd have to negotiate rights with every single publisher." The scene transitions to a similar green background with the text "TO READ" at the top, showing the same group of individuals. The speech bubble now states, "Right now, if you wanted to do that, you couldn't, because you'd have to negotiate rights with every single publisher." The right side of the frame introduces a grid of squares with a DNA strand, and a speech bubble reads, "Researcher can build new tools that can interact with articles and uncover new relationships." The scene then shifts to a blue background with the text "FREE TO READ" at the top, depicting the same group of individuals. The speech bubble reads, "Right now, if you wanted to do that, you couldn't, because you'd have to negotiate rights with every single publisher." The right side of the frame shows the same grid of squares with a DNA strand, and a speech bubble reads, "Researcher can build new tools that can interact with articles and uncover new relationships." The video concludes with a green background featuring the text "FREE TO READ" at the top, accompanied by illustrations of four individuals holding papers, seemingly engaged in reading or discussion. Below them, a speech bubble reads, "Right now, if you wanted to do that, you couldn't, because you'd have to negotiate rights with every single publisher." The right side of the frame introduces a grid of squares with a DNA strand, and a speech bubble reads, "Researcher can build new tools that can interact with articles and uncover new relationships." The bottom of the frame features a speech bubble that reads, "In an Open Access world all this would be free and unrestricted." The video emphasizes the concept of open access and the benefits of free reading and re-use of research materials.

The video begins with a white background displaying the text, "I think the main impediment is the slow movement of scientific cultural practices." This sets the theme of the video, which is about the challenges in the scientific community. The scene transitions to a cartoon of a scientist pointing to the right, accompanied by the text, "Scientists, despite being great explorers, are very conservative in changing how they do things." This highlights the resistance to change within the scientific community. The next frame shows two scientists on a large ice block, with one saying, "Yeah, I support open access... but I want a high-profile paper." This illustrates the tension between supporting open access and the desire for prestige. The following frame depicts a group of people on smaller ice blocks, with one saying, "I think the 'rain impending' scientific community is going to do things the way they always have." This suggests a reluctance to change despite the challenges. The scene then shifts to a group of people around a large blue box, with one saying, "Corporations may figure that out before governments do." This indicates the potential for corporations to lead in innovation. The next frame shows a person throwing papers into a trash can, with the text, "I'm open to whoever is going to come up with creative solutions... I view it as scientists and publishers are slow to change." This emphasizes the need for creative solutions and the slow pace of change in the scientific community. The final frame shows a group of people sitting around a table, with one saying, "Let them know this is something you care about." This encourages individuals to advocate for change. Throughout the video, the cartoon style and simple backgrounds keep the focus on the text and the message being conveyed.

The video begins with a simple, hand-drawn illustration of a person reading a paper, accompanied by a speech bubble that reads, "For the person that can read your paper, it's also good for you." This sets the theme of the importance of accessibility in academic work. The scene transitions to a more detailed illustration featuring a man with curly hair and a beard, wearing a checkered shirt, raising his arms enthusiastically. He is surrounded by people, some of whom are holding papers, and a speech bubble states, "I believe that science spreads and increases best when there are no restrictions to access." This emphasizes the message of open access in science. The narrative continues with the same man, now with an additional speech bubble that reads, "I want discovery to happen faster, and openness helps." The scene then shifts to a group of people sitting around a table, discussing and sharing papers, with a speech bubble saying, "It's really important that graduate students share their papers." This highlights the collaborative nature of academic research. The video then shows a large, blue, open book with people floating around it, reading and discussing papers, reinforcing the theme of open access. The final frames display the logo of "PhD TV" and the text "A Piled Higher and Deeper Production www.phdcomics.com/tv," indicating the production source. The video concludes with a call to action, displaying the text "Learn about your options at: openaccessweek.org," encouraging viewers to explore open access resources. The overall atmosphere is educational and supportive, promoting the benefits of open access in academic research.
